[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: I thought I smelled a Selûnite.
Isobel: At your service.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: You seem to have a lot to say about my allegiance. Can we focus on the task at hand?
Isobel: I suppose that would be wise. We have a common enemy, after all: Ketheric Thorm.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: Nod. Better to humour her than make an enemy of all in this place. Lady Shar will understand.
Isobel: Refreshingly pragmatic of you. I sense Shar has offered some amount of protection to you already, but... well, no harm in extra precaution - even from a Selûnite.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Selûne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*
InternalNodeContext: Incurable wound imagery/memoriy fragment
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus

Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him.
Isobel: A True Soul with a soul. Imagine.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.

Player: I need nothing from a Selûnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: It was nothing. Put it out of your mind.
Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.

Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: How thoughtful. And where did you find this friend?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us.
Sazza: This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one...
Nightwarden Minthara: ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: She's telling the truth. She didn't know.
Sazza: I told ya! I was tryin' to follow orders best I could!
Nightwarden Minthara: Silence, wretch. And remember - you owe your miserable life to this one.
Sazza: I won't cause any more trouble - I swears it.
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have a part to play in this slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.*
Narrator: *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.*
Narrator: *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I want no part of this.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates and crush our enemies.
Player: And I'm happy to do it - for a price.

Nightwarden Minthara: I have been expecting you. The goblins tell me that you forced a confession from our prisoner.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Nightwarden Minthara: You serve the Absolute well.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.*
Narrator: *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: The druids' magic protects the grove, but she may be able to break through.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.*
Narrator: *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Get out of my mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: Destroying this place is the Absolute's will. Would you defy Her?
Player: Open your mind to her.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...*
Narrator: *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect.
Nightwarden Minthara: If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I don't have the most trustworthy face.
Nightwarden Minthara: They're half-devil refugees... Nobody wants them.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drowning creature will cling to a blade if nothing else is offered. Be that blade.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: Reject these dreams of a bloodbath.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: There's more to it than that. The figure I saw: she means something to you.
: True
Gale: She does. She's... She's Mystra.
Gale: I can't quite describe it, the need I sometimes feel to see her - to draw the filaments of fantasy into existence.
Gale: No sculpture or painting could ever do her justice, only the fabric that she herself is and embodies:
Gale: The Weave.
Gale: Mystra is all magic. And as far as I'm concerned, she is all creation.
Player: Sounding more of a poet than a wizard there, Gale.
Gale: It's a kind of love after all.
Gale: Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it.
Gale: It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses.
Gale: Would you like to experience this?
Player: Magic normally comes to me through prayer, but I don't mind trying.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture with ease.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player imitates the gesture. There’s a first visual effect. Some sparks of magic start to appear around the player and Gale.
Narrator: *A familiar feeling - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: An easy incantation. Simply repeat after Gale.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The visual effect intensifies. There’s the start of a glow, of a rush of beautiful magic.
Narrator: *Ah, yes: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Recede into the calm centre of your mind, just like you were taught at the academy.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player and Gale are now fully enveloped in a magic glow - a protective field of beautiful magic. Unconsciously player steps back closer to Gale.
Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the unmistakable presence of Mystra, the Lady of Mysteries.*
Narrator: *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.*
Narrator: *You are safe. You are nestled in the cup of Mystra's hand.*
Gale: Look at that. We're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Gale: You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: Magical.
Gale: That it does.
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture kicking him in the gut.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Let's not let an ancient squabble interfere with the task at hand.
Isobel: Not as ancient as you think.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I may have the parasite of a True Soul, but not the mind of one.
Isobel: And that's what makes you essential.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selûnite one.
Isobel: If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: You seem especially philosophical this evening. Are you all right?
Gale: I will be, soon. I am perhaps just one hard day away from being without any troubles at all.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: Is this truly what you want, to die for the promise of Mystra's forgiveness?
Gale: Babe or crone, coward or hero, death is assured. Mystra's forgiveness is not. If you knew the end was near, would you not want to ensure it had meaning?
Gale: I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: Why are you so sure it's inevitable? We haven't even found this 'Heart of the Absolute' yet.
Gale: I can feel it - ever since we set foot in this strange, corrupted land. The closer we get, the heavier my own heart becomes.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Selûnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selûnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: Try to understand what's happening.
Narrator: *Is Lady Shar punishing you? Or perhaps testing you? Is it the tadpole, or a curse? You cannot say.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Player: Give Gale a suitable artefact.
Gale: My condition requires a delicate touch. Just one item will suffice to keep it in check.
Player: I'm not giving you anything. Not now, not ever.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.

Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: Why did you summon me here?
Gale: I wanted to see you. While I still could.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: It's a heavy burden, yes - but one you're able for. Think of the good your sacrifice will do.
Gale: I am trying. Believe me, I am. The path is set, and I will not stray from it - even as my heart quakes.
Gale: I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: Why are you so sure it's inevitable? We haven't even found this 'Heart of the Absolute' yet.
Gale: I can feel it - ever since we set foot in this strange, corrupted land. The closer we get, the heavier my own heart becomes.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Gale: There's the makings of a fine follower of Mystra within you, give or take a few decades of studying the Weave.
Gale: Now, given my magical expertise is of limited use to you, was there something else you wanted to ask me about?
Gale: What's on your mind?

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.

NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.

Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...

NodeContext: Full of longing

Gale: I am trying. Believe me, I am. The path is set, and I will not stray from it - even as my heart quakes.

Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us.
Sazza: This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one...
Nightwarden Minthara: ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: You only have to look at me to know I'm your superior, wretch.
Sazza: Somebody help!
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have a part to play in this slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.*
Narrator: *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.*
Narrator: *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I want no part of this.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates and crush our enemies.
Player: And I'm happy to do it - for a price.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: What do you have in mind?
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.

: False

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: You seem especially philosophical this evening. Are you all right?
Gale: I will be, soon. I am perhaps just one hard day away from being without any troubles at all.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: I refuse to believe this is the end. We'll find another way, I promise.
Gale: Thank you. But even if we do find another way, perhaps this is the right way. The end fate wishes for me.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You're right. At least this way, you might take the Absolute down with you.
Gale: I can only hope that there are few innocents within the Absolute's reach, when the time comes... and that you will seek safety, far away from me.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all.
Gale: Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't.
Gale: If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world.
Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Narrator: *The book is locked tight, with no visible keyhole - only an oval recess in the cover's mouth.*
Narrator: *You try to examine the book, but the longer you stare, the more those piercing, amethyst eyes draw you in.*
Narrator: *You can sense something dark about this tome - something profane.*
Lae'zel: A cursed book? How obvious. Whoever opens it deserves the fate that befalls them.
Shadowheart: Curious. Why don't you take a closer look... I'll observe from back here.

Karlach: Please don't open the creepy book.
Astarion: That looks terribly heavy. Why don't you let me carry it for you?
Wyll: We surely shouldn't just leave such a threat out, where anyone could stumble across it.
Player: Open the book.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.

Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: I'm afraid all of this is just a fantasy.
Gale: So it is. But a very fine one.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: Is this truly what you want, to die for the promise of Mystra's forgiveness?
Gale: Babe or crone, coward or hero, death is assured. Mystra's forgiveness is not. If you knew the end was near, would you not want to ensure it had meaning?
Gale: I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You're right. At least this way, you might take the Absolute down with you.
Gale: I can only hope that there are few innocents within the Absolute's reach, when the time comes... and that you will seek safety, far away from me.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all.
Gale: Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't.
Gale: If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world.
Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: It's rare people look at me and see 'hope'.
Jaheira: The light is rather dim, out here in the shadowlands. The point remains:
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.

: False

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: Whatever you're hunting, your stench alone will kill it.
Gandrel: Hah! A quick wit is rare indeed. Good manners, however, all beings can aspire to.
Gandrel: I suggest you find yours before dealing with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Why would you assume that?
Gandrel: Because this is her domain. If you are here, it is because it suits her.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: What price is that?
Gandrel: Whatever's easiest to lose and hardest to do without.
Gandrel: But the thing I hunt has gone to ground. If she can tell me how to draw him out, I'll pay whatever she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Come now - I've almost certainly killed worse.
: True
Gandrel: I would not be so sure. But I won't keep the truth from you.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You're wasting your time. Astarion's been dealt with.
Gandrel: You know him? Not too well, I think, if you believe he is so easily slain. He could be stalking your camp at this very moment.
Gandrel: Perhaps you could tell me where to look, and I could ensure peace of mind for us both?
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: Tell him how to find your camp.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.

Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong.
Vlaakith: You have ventured far from your kind's comforts to serve us.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.

Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.

Player: I spoke too hastily - please forgive me.

: True

Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.

Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.

Balthazar: ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry?
Wulbren Bongle: Well - it won't stain this beautiful city with its abominations - not anymore.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.
Wulbren Bongle: But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Enough, Wulbren! Gortash enslaved us, forced us to build his Steel Watchers - but no more.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home and mourn my daughter in peace.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: What about Gortash? What if he forces you to build up his Steel Watch once more?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: I will be long gone from this wretched city before that happens. I am no threat - I am... nothing.
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: Toobin will lie, torment, and scheme until his dying breath. Kill him - or the Ironhands will.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren - enough! I won't watch as you poison your soul - and the brilliant future that remains to the Ironhand Gnomes.
Barcus Wroot: I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around.
Barcus Wroot: Kill the Gondians, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.
Barcus Wroot: I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: Wulbren makes a good point - you must die for the city, Gondians.

Alfira: First cultists nearly murder us, and now we have a traitor on the inside? Can't we trust anyone?
NodeContext: frustrated and tired of being scared
Player: Cultists? What happened?
Alfira: Stars, you hadn't heard?

Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Ikaron again?
Alfira: Which...? He was on the quiet side, but had a heart of gold. Back in the grove, he'd kept an eye on the kids. Gods, that feels like a lifetime ago.
Alfira: Some of us fought back - or tried to. But it was hopeless.
Alfira: All I could do was run.
Player: Running was the right call.
Alfira: That means a lot, coming from you. You always seem to take everything in your stride.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: I'll let you know when I figure it out.
Alfira: We're in the same boat, then? That's... somewhat of a comfort.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: Who are you?
Gandrel: Today? The same as you - a humble supplicant, come to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Why would you assume that?
Gandrel: Because this is her domain. If you are here, it is because it suits her.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: Speak for yourself - I got what I wanted.
Gandrel: So said the fish 'round the hook in its mouth.
Gandrel: But, one fool to another, I can't say I judge you. The thing I hunt has slipped away from me.
Gandrel: If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Come now - I've almost certainly killed worse.
: True
Gandrel: I would not be so sure. But I won't keep the truth from you.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You can give up your hunt. Astarion's under my protection.
Gandrel: ...I see. Your loyalty is admirable but misplaced. His kind have charm beyond our mortal means to resist.
Gandrel: I can show you who he truly is - if you will just tell me where to find him.
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: Tell him how to find your camp.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.

He Who Was: Witness her.

Astarion: Well now, let's not throwing stones. Glass houses and all that.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.

Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.

Player: You need my help?

Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.

He Who Was: Witness her.

Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.

Gale: Thank you.
NodeContext: You look at the player with a big smile and the words are warm and heartfelt.
Player: I'm sure you're welcome.
Gale: There's that confidence I like.
Gale: I thank you for seeking me out. Amidst all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening.
Gale: More's the pity you've already found someone else to make merry with, just the two of you.
Gale: He has a certain charm about him, Astarion. Then again, so does a tiger when it purrs.
Gale: Far be it from me of course, to question your tastes.
Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Wyll.
Gale: Indeed?
Gale: We shared a romantic moment of the mind while cloaked in the Weave, didn't we?
Gale: And I seem to recall a fond allusion to that moment afterwards.
Gale: Allow me to make the following proposition:
Gale: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen.
Gale: They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired.
Gale: The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself.
Gale: I say we take a page from their book.
Player: Leave it to you to woo someone with a book.
Gale: Forget the book then. Let's be blank slates on blank sheets, delightfully new.
Gale: What do you say?
Player: I'm afraid I have to decline.
Gale: Too bad. One should never be afraid to live life to the fullest.

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: I heard what happened - that people were taken to Moonrise.
Alfira: I keep replaying it... over and over in my head.
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?

Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.

Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.

NodeContext: frustrated and tired of being scared

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.

Gandrel: A powerful friend. A terrible foe. That, I cannot decide for you.
Gandrel: For my part - I need her knowledge. The thing I hunt has gone to ground.
Gandrel: If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.

: True

Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.

Gandrel: Perhaps you could tell me where to look, and I could ensure peace of mind for us both?
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?

NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.

Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.

Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?

Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Something called the Nightsong. Your notes were very interesting.

Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: You are a ship without a sail, necromancer. You need allies - you need me.
Player: It's simple - you need me. Don't pretend otherwise.
: True
Balthazar: ...Fine. Your usefulness may outweigh your insolence - for now. There are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: You're a monster hunter? Not what I imagined.
Gandrel: Hah. Perhaps that is why I have survived so long where more fearsome peers have not.
Gandrel: You would be wise to look past the seeming of things, if you intend to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Why would you assume that?
Gandrel: Because this is her domain. If you are here, it is because it suits her.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: Speak plainly. What is she?
Gandrel: A powerful friend. A terrible foe. That, I cannot decide for you.
Gandrel: For my part - I need her knowledge. The thing I hunt has gone to ground.
Gandrel: If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: I like danger. The truth - now.
: True
Gandrel: Perhaps I was... hasty with my words.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: I know Astarion - he's no vampire.
Gandrel: So you have met him. His kind have charm beyond our mortal means to resist.
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered.
He Who Was: Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: Let's see what she has to say first.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Gale: Come now - you're hardly in position to cast judgement on that score, are you?
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: If it was drunk complaining, why did you report them?
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar said to report everythin', big or small. She ain't the type you say no to.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
: True
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Start stabbing, and don't stop until I say so.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Did I say stop? Drive the knife in deeper.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: Whatever you're hunting, your stench alone will kill it.
Gandrel: Hah! A quick wit is rare indeed. Good manners, however, all beings can aspire to.
Gandrel: I suggest you find yours before dealing with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Are you talking about Auntie Ethel?
Gandrel: A gentle name. But I speak of her nature.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: Speak plainly. What is she?
Gandrel: A powerful friend. A terrible foe. That, I cannot decide for you.
Gandrel: For my part - I need her knowledge. The thing I hunt has gone to ground.
Gandrel: If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: I like danger. The truth - now.
: True
Gandrel: Perhaps I was... hasty with my words.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: We've met - he's not the type to come quietly.
Gandrel: You do know him? I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?

NodeContext: Whispered

NodeContext: Whispered

NodeContext: Whispered

Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.

Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Gale: Let's give them a hand, shall we? Only decent course of action, if you ask me.
Player: Excellent. I can add Philomeen's head to my collection.

Player: You think a few shadows could beat me?
Alfira: ...Wait. No one's told you?
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Wandering into the darkness was a stupid idea.
Alfira: And I regret it with every breath.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: A strong weapon-arm and a bit of luck. That's all you need.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul.
Araj Oblodra: I'd like to offer my services, if you're willing?
Player: I'm listening.
Araj Oblodra: Put plainly - I'd like your blood. A vial of True Soul's blood, specifically.
Araj Oblodra: With one drop, I can brew a rather potent potion for you. The rest, I keep for myself.
Player: Sounds interesting. Let's do it.
Araj Oblodra: Just a little prick and it's all over. Close your eyes.
Araj Oblodra: A little pain for a lot of gold. And...
Araj Oblodra: There we are. All of your very best traits in a bottle. Use it well!
Araj Oblodra: Although perhaps there's one more thing we could discuss: your friend.
Araj Oblodra: He's a vampire, no? Or one of their spawn, at least.

Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-

Araj Oblodra: I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it.
Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.

Astarion: I'm sorry, but could you excuse us a moment?

Astarion: Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *Your vision throbs with ink-black darkness as your patron borrows your gaze - beholding the vision in front of you.*
Narrator: *Not exactly a god - but not far off. Your patron recoils, but not before leaving a word of advice - caution.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Kneel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kneels, head bowed, solemn, appropriate. Vlaakith offers something resembling a smile, and gestures for the player to rise. The player rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Astarion: You're what? That is the only thing keeping us from a gruesome, tentacled-filled future.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong.
Vlaakith: Your kind will go far for glory. As you have shown by being here.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Player: The god-queen of my people cannot kill someone herself?
Vlaakith: Perhaps I misheard. You would not speak ill of a god. Would you?
Player: I spoke too hastily - please forgive me.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: # Mizora's Exit sequence #
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Just what are you up to?
Mizora: I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: What are you proposing?
Mizora: A life for a life. No contract is ended without sacrifice. The cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact. You are freed from your duty but retain your devil form. Your father dies by his enemy's hand.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Leave him dead. When the city's free, you can take his place.

Narrator: *You stand before the mysterious mace once more.*
Narrator: *A fist-sized piece of amber flecked with crimson is set in the handle, emitting a radiance all its own.*
: True
Narrator: *This mace must be the legendary Blood of Lathander - the amber is said to contain the blood of the Morninglord himself.*

Shadowheart: We should leave that thing and just get out of here while we can.

Narrator: *The glow around the mace sparkles with beautiful disaster.*
Narrator: *You recall all the measures meant to keep you from reaching this place.*
Narrator: *Taking this mace would surely lead to something quite disastrous.*
Narrator: *The brutal aches in your body yearn to take it, though you sense it will spell misfortune.*

: True

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_HaarlepDouble: Hmmmm... you are so, so delicious.

Narrator: *As she continues to lavish herself upon your helpless form, you stop breathing, your heart stops beating, and your mind begins to clear entirely.*
Narrator: *Some last thought whispers in your skull, vacated by everything else but rapture -*
Narrator: *'This is the end.'*

: False

Cerys: Thought you'd be ten yards tall, the way Zevlor spoke of you.
NodeContext: Blunt, eyeing us up (friendly, not unimpressed - but muted due to circumstances)
Cerys: Cerys. Scout. Seems we missed one another at the grove, but the others told me how you helped us.
Cerys: A pity. You pulled them from one death-trap only for me to land them in this one.
Player: I heard you were ambushed by the cult. It sounded brutal.
Cerys: Aye. Not a battle she's likely to put to song. Maybe we should have just surrendered - Zevlor begged us to. But...
Cerys: They were toying with us. Making examples. And we'd had enough of taking it.
Cerys: Those of us who cut free just kept running 'til we found this place. The others... maybe the cult got them. Maybe the curse.
Player: So you abandoned them.

Harper Meygan: He was joking, this morning. Yonas, I mean.

Harper Meygan: He was a good Harper. A good friend...

Harper Meygan: I... yes, I'd like that. I don't know what to say.

Shadowheart: You're here. Just like it told me. And with a gith - I should have figured.

Shadowheart: It took me so long to find you.

Shadowheart: Quiet! I can't... concentrate with all these voices! Just listen.
Shadowheart: The whispering won't let me sleep. It keeps pushing me - to you.
Shadowheart: Even when I'm awake, I dream. There's blood, there's so much blood.
Shadowheart: I can't sleep. The whispering won't let me. It keeps pushing me - to you.
NodeContext: On, " to you" SH's hand drifts toward a knife tucked into her belt at the small her back

: True
Narrator: *There is a knife hidden in her belt. Her fingers twitch towards the hilt, ready to draw the blade.*
Player: Slow down - what whispering?
Shadowheart: They've been in my head ever since... it doesn't matter. They brought me here.
Shadowheart: I keep thinking about the knife going deep. It's the only thing they want me to see.
Shadowheart: And I think they'll stop once I deal with you.
Player: You can't kill me just because some 'whispers' told you to.
Shadowheart: I can't see anything else! I can't shake it.
Shadowheart: The whispering's already quieter here. Once you're dead, it'll be gone entirely.

Sceleritas Fel: Master. You are the chosen one.
NodeContext: Awestruck
Sceleritas Fel: He is near... He comes for you.
NodeContext: Butler's body beginning to vibrate, and jerk strangely
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The butler levitates, held up in the air like a broken marionette on invisible strings. Daggers manifest in the air around him and plunge into his body, making a gory pincusion of him. His mutilated corpse crashes to the ground, and the blood that runs from it forms a dark pool.

A light glows within the pool, and within the reflection, we see the Bhaal Temple - the eyes of the skull light with flame within the reflection, and a figure moves out of the darkness toward the surface of the pool, where it connects to reality. It is the butler, his hat gone, the flesh peeled back from his skull in places. Thoroughly mutilated and disfigured. His eyes burn with unholy fire - he has become an Avatar of Bhaal.

Bhaal Avatar: Child of slaughter. I come to give you your inheritance.
Bhaal Avatar: I have a gift for you, Child. You will use it to lacerate this world.
Narrator: *A gift from your god, your Father. An offering of his affection for you, or confirmation that he owns you.*
Narrator: *Accept Father's gift and you will reap horrors upon this world. But you will be his puppet. This is your final chance to cut your strings...*
GROUP_ORI_DU: What gift does the Lord of Murder propose?
Bhaal Avatar: My Slayer. You will grow stronger. Crueller. The prime incarnation of murder.
GROUP_ORI_DU: No god gives selflessly. What do you ask in return?
Bhaal Avatar: Domination. Slaughter. Mountains of corpses, you standing atop them.
Bhaal Avatar: You must destroy this world. It is what you were made for.
Narrator: *For a moment, the brine-pool of your brain clears. To die: to rest, to save the world from yourself. To accept: to become his prophet - in any disobedience, subject to his lash.*
GROUP_ORI_DU: Every night you can possess me, my friends' lives are in danger. I will not stand for that.
Bhaal Avatar: You refuse me?
Bhaal Avatar: You are my spawn. Your veins course with my unholy blood.
Bhaal Avatar: Your life is mine. Accept your inheritance, or I will reclaim it.
GROUP_ORI_DU: I don't have a choice, it seems. This is what I am.

GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.
Player: Ready yourself for a fight.

Gale: I was supposed to sacrifice myself to stop the Absolute - yet I don't think I could have gone through with it, in truth. And I'm glad that I didn't, given what has come to light.
Gale: I can't help but feel like I've been fumbling in the dark for too long, and have just had a lit torch thrust into my hands.
Player: What are you talking about?
Gale: The crown. The one the elder brain was wearing.
Gale: Netherese magic. So pure - so complete - that I didn't even recognise it at first...
Gale: Most Netherese artefacts contain only the faintest amount of their former power - the ghost of an echo of a memory... that crown was different.
Gale: I can't fathom how such a wonder survived - surely everything of its ilk was destroyed along with Netheril itself... but no matter. It exists, and I must learn more of it.
Player: What do you suggest?
Gale: We need to learn more about what we saw. An artefact as powerful as that crown must have been documented somewhere.
Gale: As luck would have it, we'll soon find ourselves near one of the finest book collections this side of Candlekeep - Sorcerous Sundries. I need to go there, and learn all I can.
Player: No, Gale.

Player: Fine. Take it all.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: Who are you?
Gandrel: Today? The same as you - a humble supplicant, come to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Not at all. I was invited for tea.
Gandrel: Of course - as the spider invites the fly. You need something, I expect. And she sensed it.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: What price is that?
Gandrel: Whatever's easiest to lose and hardest to do without.
Gandrel: But the thing I hunt has gone to ground. If she can tell me how to draw him out, I'll pay whatever she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Come now - I've almost certainly killed worse.
: True
Gandrel: I would not be so sure. But I won't keep the truth from you.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You can give up your hunt. Astarion's under my protection.
Gandrel: ...I see. Your loyalty is admirable but misplaced. His kind have charm beyond our mortal means to resist.
Gandrel: I can show you who he truly is - if you will just tell me where to find him.
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: Tell him how to find your camp.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry?
Wulbren Bongle: Well - it won't stain this beautiful city with its abominations - not anymore.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.
Wulbren Bongle: But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.

Gondian Menalda: If you let us go, you will never hear from us again - I swear it.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: He's right. It's over.
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: Toobin will lie, torment, and scheme until his dying breath. Kill him - or the Ironhands will.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.

Barcus Wroot: Kill the Gondians, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.
Barcus Wroot: I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.

Araj Oblodra: Araj Oblodra, trader in blood and the sanguineous arts. It is a pleasure to stand before a True Soul. And your pale companion.
NodeContext: With a bow. (Araj Oblodra = a-RADJ o-BLOD-ruh)
Araj Oblodra: I'd like to offer my services, if you're willing?
Player: Why are you interested in my pale friend?
Araj Oblodra: Please, you think someone in my line of work wouldn't recognise a vampire spawn when they see one?
Araj Oblodra: I trade in blood and the potions that can be wrung from it. I'm more than happy to make you one, if you'd honour me with your blood.
Araj Oblodra: With one drop, I can brew a rather potent potion for you. The rest, I keep for myself.
Player: Sounds interesting. Let's do it.
Araj Oblodra: Just a little prick and it's all over. Close your eyes.
Araj Oblodra: A little pain for a lot of gold. And...
Araj Oblodra: There we are. All of your very best traits in a bottle. Use it well!
Araj Oblodra: Although perhaps there's one more thing we could discuss: your friend.
Araj Oblodra: He's a vampire, no? Or one of their spawn, at least.
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did.
Araj Oblodra: I assume he belongs to you?
Player: We travel together - that's all.
Araj Oblodra: Ah, it's like that.
