Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it.
Araj Oblodra: I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it.
Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?

Astarion: I'm sorry, but could you excuse us a moment?
Astarion: Are you actually asking me to do this? Trading me for some potion?
Astarion: Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.

Araj Oblodra: I don't have all day, True Soul.

Astarion: All right. Thank you.

He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.

Lord Enver Gortash: You have the Netherstones - they resonate with my own.
Lord Enver Gortash: I commend you for putting an end to Orin's madness - she must be screaming bloody murder in the Hells even now.
Lord Enver Gortash: How was the reunion? I trust you demonstrated your particular spark of creative genius?
Lord Enver Gortash: I always preferred your methods to hers. You have mastery over your Urges, Orin was consumed by her gruesome obsessions.
Player: Atonement is what I seek now.
Lord Enver Gortash: Whatever happened in that Temple, it doesn't change what you're guilty of, and the rewards your guilt will sow.

Lord Enver Gortash: You can be my equal.

Lord Enver Gortash: Your bones will be a souvenir of what could've been.

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?

Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.

Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?

Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?

Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: # Mizora's Exit sequence #
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Just what are you up to?
Mizora: I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Narrator: *Your parasite links with Wyll's, and your memories flow into him. He sees his father's flight from Wyrm's Rock and hears Mizora's words to you.*
Wyll: Shit. Where did Gortash send my father? How do I save him?
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: Then break it already. Wyll has suffered enough.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.

Fezzerk: Look what we got here - another little birdie wantin' to fly!
NodeContext: Cruel bravado.The goblin sees the player approach and boldly announces it to his cronies - he thinks some fresh victims have just turned up.
Fezzerk: Yehehueh! Enjoyin' yerself? Sun ain't too bright in those beady little eyes?
NodeContext: Greatly amused. A schoolyard bully. Projecting his voice a little (Fezzerk calls out to taunt his deep gnome prisoner, who rotates on the sail of a windmill a short-moderate distance off.)
'Yehehueh!' = Fezzerk's distinct laugh (a raspy, mean-spirited slur of a laugh)
Fezzerk: An' you - hope you got a stomach fer heights!
NodeContext: Confident, unpleasant. Turning his attention to the player to deliver a threat.
Player: I'm not looking for trouble - just want to pass by.
Fezzerk: Heh, funny. That's what our birdie wanted.
Barcus Wroot: ...Release me this instant, you beasts!
NodeContext: Panicked, angry. Issuing an ultimatum even though he has no means of following through on it.
Fezzerk: 'Less you wanna join him up there, you'd best pay the toll.
NodeContext: Fezzerk mockingly refers to the deep gnome's predicament as he threatens the player. 'Passing by' refers to rotating on a windmill rather than safe passage through the area, in his book.
Fezzerk: Cough it up! ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
NodeContext: Fezzerk declares his price. (A ridiculously high sum - questionable whether he truly knows how absurd a demand this is)
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Player: Here's my counter-offer: a far more reasonable sum. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_3_01f129ea-b4dc-44b6-8154-9a948f876a82])
Player: I might be willing to part with a more reasonable sum. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_5_8860ed48-ba5f-4b7b-82bf-f1220f967d41])
: True
Fezzerk: You wanna haggle? Fine. The price has just doubled!
Fezzerk: How do you like that? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])
Player: I've changed my mind - release the gnome and clear off. Or else.
Fezzerk: Or else what, you'll fight us? Bit late to find some backbone, don't you reckon?
Fezzerk: You want this little cave-lurkin' wotsit?
Fezzerk: Find your own! He's ours an' we ain't sharin'!
Fezzerk: Find your own! He's ours!
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Player: Negotiations are over. Either leave or die.
: True
Narrator: *The goblin's nostrils flare, as if trying to judge you through smell alone...*
NodeContext: Narration
Fezzerk: Apologies, your grace. We didn't mean to doubt a True Soul. We'll be off.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: We share a profession, it seems. I'm Wyll - better known as the Blade of Frontiers.
Gandrel: Ah, the Blade of Frontiers! You wield that reputation as deftly as a blade itself.
Gandrel: Your name should serve you well when you meet with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: It's a teahouse - hardly a lair.
Gandrel: A charming sight, to be sure. But the prettiest web still has a spider sitting at its centre.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: I think you're mistaken - this place looks innocent enough.
Gandrel: That would be nice. I'd welcome a proper cup of tea.
Gandrel: But I'm not wrong. Take her lightly, and she'll serve up your eyes for appetisers.
Gandrel: I'll eat them, too. I need her knowledge - the thing I hunt has gone to ground.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Your coyness is getting boring. Tell me.
: True
Gandrel: You take insult where none is intended, my friend. But fine - I won't add to it.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: We've met - he's not the type to come quietly.
Gandrel: You do know him? I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: I'm not going to help you find him. Back off.

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Patience does not delay, it simply tempers virtue. Curtails it from excess.
Havkelaag: A cautious, hesitant instinct. One I am afraid we do not have time for.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?
Halsin: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: This magic you mentioned - it isn't normal for these parasites?
Player: Then everything we did here was hopeless.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: I'll deal with this. You get to safety.
Halsin: I told you, nowhere is safe. Not while this rot festers. Once it is cut out - once the grove is secure - then I shall leave.
Player: Follow me, then. Your bear form may prove useful.
Halsin: Be warned - my presence could make things more difficult... I can only restrain my bear form so much. I won't be able to help but attack goblins.
Halsin: If I join you, we'll likely have to slaughter this entire place. You may want to use discretion when approaching the goblin leaders.
Player: Come with me.
Halsin: So be it. May Silvanus lend us nature's fury.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Our time has come, son. Together, we will usher in a new dawn.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.
Narrator: *The Duke wants to keep Florrick's location a secret. Little does he know that you've already found and freed her.*
Player: Connect with Ravengard's parasite to seek information about Florrick.
: True

Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Faerûn suffers in darkness. Tyr has abandoned us; Helm's eye has strayed.
Narrator: *Tyr's fury glows within you. Despite Ravengard's words, the Lord of Justice has remained loyal to you, as you have to him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: But Baldur's Gate will soon burn bright. A beacon to light the heavens.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: And it will be Gortash who ignites the final spark.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Dribbles stands atop the stage, a big smile on his face. Group of children crowded at the front.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Buddy the dog is my very best friend. Do you know why?
Quinton: Why?
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Because with him, anything is paw-sible. Wa-hey!
NodeContext: Big gestures at the 'wa-hey' (it's his 'signature' sound). Maybe jazz hands or a little dance?
Lae'zel: Can we not find a more pleasant amusement? Gouging out our own eyeballs, perhaps?
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Did you hear about the scarecrow who lost a fight?
Player: Simply watch.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: He got the stuffing kicked out of him. Wa-hey!
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Oh, oh, you're all such good friends! I've had a wonderful time, but I have to go...
Dolia: Awww.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Oh, well, if you INSIST. How about a magic trick? But first - I need a volunteer with nerves of steel and the heart of a lion!
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Who will it be? Who...?
NodeContext: Puts his hands to his eyes and dramatically scans the crowd - suddenly locks eyes with the player.
Narrator: *A prickling hum runs through your very being - your patron does not trust this clown. Not one bit.*
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: You - my special assistant. Come on up.
Player: This clown's looking at you funny. What's his deal?
: False
Narrator: *You stare, but glean no ill-intent from the clown. Perhaps the makeup just threw you off.*
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Come now, don't be a Cowardly Connie. Perhaps you need a little encouragement?
NodeContext: looks at crowd expectantly, raising his hands to 'give it up' for the player.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Now, up, up, double sharp! Or poor Buddy here might think you don't like him.
Player: Approach the stage warily, keeping an eye out.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

He Who Was: Where lies your guilt?
NodeContext: Shadar-Kai speaks in a cold, calculated tone.
Madeline: The... Waning Moon...
NodeContext: Speak with dead style
Player: What's going on here?
He Who Was: You walk in the darkness, unafraid? How curious.
Raven: *CAW.*
He Who Was: A fair point - perhaps this one could assist us.
He Who Was: The murdered lie silent. The raven asks - will you be their voice?
: True
Narrator: *The raven, the piercings, the general malaise: this is a shadar-kai. Tales and songs featuring servants of the Raven Queen tend to be tragedies.*
Player: Speak plainly - what are you talking about?
He Who Was: Forgive me - it has been some time since I spoke to another.
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: It sounds like she must be punished - thoroughly.
He Who Was: You see it as I do.
He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: That's some powerful magic.
He Who Was: Not for one such as I.
He Who Was: Your soul sparks with vengeance. With fury. This is your chance to torment a murderer. To make her suffer.
He Who Was: Will you take it?
Player: I will - what must I do?

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?
Player: Do not demand answers of me, yank. Tell me what happened here.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: So you killed them?
Ptaris: It is not my fault they died. I was only upholding father's code. Even he was not strong enough to follow it.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I like to think so.
Ptaris: If you only think, then you do not know.
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: The Ptarian code? Then you follow the teachings of Bahamut?
Ptaris: The purest of your rulers. But you are nothing like him. You are tainted.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: You feel strange, don't you? That's your conscience. It's telling you to stop.
Ptaris: My - my what?

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: This experiment is exactly the kind of evil you're trying to disprove.
Havkelaag: The pursuit of knowledge is neither evil nor good. Only in the application of such knowledge should one take on any moral imperative.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I am a scholar, this is true - just not in the study of torture.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
: True
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: You do me an honour, but I am not worthy. Show me the way of Shar - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Wyll: You just have to buy enough time to run. Come on. I believe in you. You can do this.
Player: Hey there. Can I have a word?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll turns to you, smiling.
Wyll: Well met. The Blade of Frontiers at your -
Narrator: *The man's smile bends downward, and his thoughts become yours.*
Narrator: *You are the Blade of Frontiers, racing through the wastes of Avernus. Just ahead, a diabolical figure - red skin, single curled horn - blazes with flame, bloodied greataxe held high.*
Narrator: *It's Karlach - the woman you met in the wilds.*
Wyll: Hells' great fires - you were on the ship.
Player: Another escapee? Thank the gods - I need all the friends I can get.
Wyll: Better friends than the ones hitching a ride in our skulls, at least.
Wyll: I'm sure you know the stories. Doomed to shed our skin and become illithid. They say there's no coming back.
Wyll: But we haven't sprouted any tentacles - not yet, anyway. Could just be good luck. I'm not so...
Narrator: *Your minds collide once more. Wyll chases the fiend, ignited with rancour. She is an infernal wardevil, a threat to the living - evil incarnate.*
Wyll: Shit - you saw her: advocatus diaboli.
: False
Narrator: *Advocatus diaboli. A devil's advocate - a champion in the Blood War between diabolical forces and demons.*
Player: I met a group of paladins who were also seeking this devil.
Wyll: I'm not surprised. My target is well-known for her brutality in service of her evil mistress.
Wyll: Her name is Karlach. An archdevil's soldier I swore on my good eye to kill.
Wyll: I tracked her through the Hells to the mind flayer ship. But the damned illithids infected me before I could end her.
Wyll: She's out there now, preying on the innocent. I don't kill her, she'll leave behind nothing but a trail of corpses.
Player: You have a mind flayer tadpole in your head. Doesn't that worry you?
Wyll: I'd be a fool if it didn't. I know the stories - doomed to shed my skin, become illithid. And there's no coming back.
Wyll: But I haven't sprouted any tentacles - least not yet, thank Balduran.
Wyll: Could just be good luck. But sooner or later, it's bound to run out.
Player: Join me, then. We'll search for a cure.
Lae'zel: Chk - a worthy ally, perhaps. But I'll waste no time chasing devils while a tadpole feasts on our skulls.
Wyll: I'm up for the challenge. You've just got to make a little space.
Player: All right. Meet me at camp.
Wyll: A splendid plan. We'll talk more there.

Rugan: By the gods, you're a sweet sight.
Rugan: Are any of my crew still alive out there?
Player: No. It's a grim sight.
Rugan: This whole journey's been one grim sight after another. Gnolls, goblins... drow.
Rugan: Risen Road's more dangerous than ever. You're the first friendly face we've seen since Elturgard.
Player: Elturgard's a long way from here. Where are you heading?
Rugan: We're bound for Baldur's Gate - got some cargo to deliver. But we've a stop to make along the way.
Player: Where's that?
Rugan: Waukeen's Rest. It's just up the road. I'd be enjoying a mug of ale right now if those beasts hadn't jumped us.
Rugan: Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself.
Rugan: You should meet my associates. We've got our own drinking spot by the tavern - invitation only.
Rugan: Tell the fellow on the door 'little serpent, long shadow'. He'll take good care of you.
Olly: Rugan!
Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: What's in the chest? Your cargo?
Rugan: Aye. The whole reason we're in this mess. Trinkets for some rich tosser in Baldur's Gate.
Rugan: He gets his shiny baubles, we get a handful of Tarenths.
: True
Narrator: *Tarenths are the currency of a merchant network called the Zhentarim. Led by the mysterious Pereghost of Darkhold, their dealings are far from scrupulous.*
Player: You're Zhent - I'd wager more than just your crew have died over these 'baubles'.
Rugan: You know who we are - very clever. Then you probably also know it's not smart to interfere with Zhent business.
Rugan: This is the point when a clever operator like you accepts my gratitude and walks away.
Player: You're missing a golden opportunity. Report the cargo lost - and we can sell it ourselves.
Player: You'll find I'm very persuasive. We can make much more coin than you would with your employers.
: False
Rugan: Coin ain't any use to the dead. And dead's what I'll be if I welch on this deal.
Rugan: Let's go our separate ways, and be thankful we're all in one piece.
Player: You had your chance. Either way, that cargo's mine.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Darkness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: What are you proposing?
Mizora: A life for a life. No contract is ended without sacrifice. The cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact. You are freed from your duty but retain your devil form. Your father dies by his enemy's hand.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!

Mizora: Choose.
Player: Do the right thing. Give your soul so that your father can live.

Havkelaag: I say - that wasn't a githyanki egg you were fiddling around with, was it?
Havkelaag: How would you like to sell it to the Society of Brilliance? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I am a scholar, this is true - just not in the study of torture.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
: True
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.

Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
: True
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: In my years of study, I have found no better teacher than example. Perhaps you could volunteer?
: True
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Gale: Even in such fraught times as these, there is peace to be found in the stillness as evening draws in.
Gale: I used to while away many hours just like these with my companion, though in far comfier surrounds.
Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: Are you... are you talking about your cat?
Gale: By Ahghairon's lost nose - no!
Gale: Tara is not any cat. She's a tressym. And given your confusion, I'm guessing you've never met one. They're brilliant creatures - fine company for any self-respecting wizard.
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be most impressed by our efforts saving these tieflings. Proud, even. And I've given her little to be proud of recently.
Gale: After I was afflicted with my condition, I locked myself in my tower for an entire year. I was inconsolable, wallowing in my self-inflicted tragedy.
Gale: I'd given up on myself, but Tara never did. It was her encouragement, her research that led me to my treatment. Once we knew that magically-infused items were the key, she went out to find them for me. She saved my life.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: What is Tara like?
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. Something in the way you roll your eyes when I speak...
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: She sounds like a fine animal. One I'd be honoured to know.
Gale: She'll love you. So long as you don't rub her belly. She hates it when anyone does that.
Player: Not as much as I hate talking about cats. Is there nothing else on your mind?
Gale: Not an animal lover? Nobody's perfect, I suppose.
Gale: Nonetheless, your finer qualities are remarkably plentiful.
Gale: Suffice it to say, I think rather a lot of you. And there aren't many on this plane who I'd give such high praise.
Player: Being mentioned in the same breath as your pet isn't the compliment you think it is...
Gale: Then let me say it more plainly -
Gale: I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: The feeling's mutual - you're a wonderful friend. Though usually more... erudite.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: What wrong has this man done to deserve such torture?
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: 'Only with sacrifice is mastery gained.' For the sisters to learn, you must submit.
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes. Submit I must, into the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: What lesson are you teaching these sisters?
Malus Thorm: The crux of our worship.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Darkness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Karlach: What the fuck is this loon talking about.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?

Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.

Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: I like danger. The truth - now.
: True
Gandrel: Perhaps I was... hasty with my words.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You can give up your hunt. Astarion's under my protection.
Gandrel: ...I see. Your loyalty is admirable but misplaced. His kind have charm beyond our mortal means to resist.
Gandrel: I can show you who he truly is - if you will just tell me where to find him.
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: I'm not going to help you find him. Back off.

Kith'rak Voss: What easy prey you make, walking right within my blade's embrace.
Kith'rak Voss: These creatures are so simple to ensnare, Baretha. You mewl too much about your task.
Sarth Baretha: Forgiveness, Kith'rak.
Kith'rak Voss: And as for you, tell me - why shouldn't I run you through this instant?
Player: I just want passage - if I have to go through you, so be it.
: True
Kith'rak Voss: Chk! You dare speak to me like my better? Others have died for lesser insults - slowly.
Kith'rak Voss: But your bravery amuses me. Finally I find a wolf in a world of lowing cattle...
Kith'rak Voss: You may live. For the moment.
Kith'rak Voss: Now, we seek a weapon, taken from a vessel that fell from the sky. Understand, istik?
Narrator: *You suddenly feel a strange anxiety take hold - not your own, but that of the artefact you carry. Somehow, it's afraid...*
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the gith raiders' hands.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the giths' suspicion cannot be aroused. They cannot discover that the weapon they seek is right within their grasp.*
Kith'rak Voss: Help us find it and I will leave your blood beneath your skin, unspilled.
Shadowheart: Don't help them. Don't tell them a thing. We're dead if you do.
Player: I might know something. But it'll cost you.
Kith'rak Voss: You haggle with your own life, fool. Be silent and hold still...
Narrator: *He begins to move his hand in a quick flurry of gestures.*
NodeContext: Narration.
Player: Silently interpret the meaning of the gestures.
: True
Narrator: *You realise he's casting Detect Thoughts.*
Player: Resist the probing into your mind.
: True
Kith'rak Voss: Bah! Nothing even approaching a useful thought in that skull. I ought to just kill you...
Player: Give it a try. I'm hungry for a little fun.
: True
Kith'rak Voss: So bold in the face of death... Perhaps you may live after all.
Kith'rak Voss: Better to let stronger blood thrive. It can give rise to worthier foes and hardier slaves. Don't disappoint me.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: It's been a while, my friend. I saw the explosion from across the pond - should've known you'd be right in the thick of it.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.
Wulbren Bongle: But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Enough, Wulbren! Gortash enslaved us, forced us to build his Steel Watchers - but no more.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: Toobin is right. It's over.
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren - enough! I won't watch as you poison your soul - and the brilliant future that remains to the Ironhand Gnomes.
Barcus Wroot: I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around.
Barcus Wroot: Kill the Gondians, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.
Barcus Wroot: I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: LEAVE, LITTLE WULBREN. OR DIE.

Alfira: I'm afraid doubt is all I know these days.
Alfira: I still can't believe it. The cultists. The screams...
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: A strong weapon-arm and a bit of luck. That's all you need.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Perhaps not. Patience is important, but cannot impede the other virtues.
Havkelaag: Then we are in accord - the time for action is now.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Arka: Can't say I understand that. Not sure I want to.

Oliver: Boo! I scared you - I saw it. Nobody beats me at hide and seek.
Halsin: That's him - like an echo of Thaniel, remoulded by the curse. We need him, if we're to put a stop to all of this.

Player: In a moment maybe. Have you seen another little boy? His name is Thaniel.

Oliver: Now play with me.

Oliver: Killed? Nobody dies around here, silly. Not like that. Play with me, and you'll see for yourself.

Oliver: They don't need names. They just need to be mummy and daddy, and do what I want. Now play with me, or they'll be angry with you.
: False

Oliver: You shouldn't be nasty. You should just do what I want. It's easier for you, that way.
Oliver: I'm not going anywhere. I like it here. Now play with me, or else.
Player: You want to play? Fine.
Oliver: All right. I'll hide, and you seek.
Halsin: Let's make this quick. We need to reunite him with Thaniel.
NodeContext: Urgent. Whispered.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: You're a monster hunter? Not what I imagined.
Gandrel: Hah. Perhaps that is why I have survived so long where more fearsome peers have not.
Gandrel: You would be wise to look past the seeming of things, if you intend to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: 'The lady of this house'?
Gandrel: A more innocent name than some I could call her. But it is what she is that ought to concern you.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: What price is that?
Gandrel: Whatever's easiest to lose and hardest to do without.
Gandrel: But the thing I hunt has gone to ground. If she can tell me how to draw him out, I'll pay whatever she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Your coyness is getting boring. Tell me.
: True
Gandrel: You take insult where none is intended, my friend. But fine - I won't add to it.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?

Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: Just kill them already - all this torture is pointless.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: The sisters require a willing volunteer, a master of the art.
: True
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
: True
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?

Fezzerk: Look what we got here - another little birdie wantin' to fly!
NodeContext: Cruel bravado.The goblin sees the player approach and boldly announces it to his cronies - he thinks some fresh victims have just turned up.
Fezzerk: Yehehueh! Enjoyin' yerself? Sun ain't too bright in those beady little eyes?
NodeContext: Greatly amused. A schoolyard bully. Projecting his voice a little (Fezzerk calls out to taunt his deep gnome prisoner, who rotates on the sail of a windmill a short-moderate distance off.)
'Yehehueh!' = Fezzerk's distinct laugh (a raspy, mean-spirited slur of a laugh)
Fezzerk: An' you - hope you got a stomach fer heights!
NodeContext: Confident, unpleasant. Turning his attention to the player to deliver a threat.
Player: I'm not looking for trouble - just want to pass by.
Fezzerk: Heh, funny. That's what our birdie wanted.
Barcus Wroot: ...Release me this instant, you beasts!
NodeContext: Panicked, angry. Issuing an ultimatum even though he has no means of following through on it.
Fezzerk: 'Less you wanna join him up there, you'd best pay the toll.
NodeContext: Confident, threatening. Thinks he holds all the cards in a one-sided negotiation.
Fezzerk: Cough it up! ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
NodeContext: Fezzerk declares his price. (A ridiculously high sum - questionable whether he truly knows how absurd a demand this is)
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Player: I might be willing to part with a more reasonable sum. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_5_8860ed48-ba5f-4b7b-82bf-f1220f967d41])
: True
Fezzerk: You wanna haggle? Fine. The price has just doubled!
Fezzerk: How do you like that? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])
Player: I've changed my mind - release the gnome and clear off. Or else.
Fezzerk: Or else what, you'll fight us? Bit late to find some backbone, don't you reckon?
Fezzerk: You want this little cave-lurkin' wotsit?
Fezzerk: Find your own! He's ours!
Narrator: *A strange symbol glows, marked on their flesh, and something within you stirs in response.*
Player: I am a True Soul. Now once again - release the gnome.
: True
Fezzerk: I... yes. Whatever you want.
Narrator: *Your mind is full, bursting with ecstasy and terror. Finally, it is coming. You are becoming.*
Narrator: *The goblin's nostrils flare nervously. All of his bluster seems to vanish.*
Fezzerk: We're leaving.
Goblin Devout: What about the gnome? Ain't we s'posed to bring him to -
Fezzerk: I said we're leaving!
Fezzerk: There's plenty of sport an' rich pickings out there fer us. Move it!

Novice Grumm: Shit - True Soul Nere's nothing but grub-chow now.
Novice Grumm: Listen up, bastards - I'm taking charge. Clean your 'nads and pack up.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Novice Grumm: We're marching to Moonrise. And no death-curse'll be stopping us.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Novice Grumm: Time for the General to recognise us duergar that have been toiling 'round here.
Player: What about the gnomes? What happens to them?
Novice Grumm: What - you'd think I'd just toss 'em? They're coming with me. A gift for the General.
Wyll: Speak up. You can't just let the clan keep them.
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Narrator: *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*
Player: Enter his mind. 'Release the gnomes.'
Novice Grumm: I... I was wrong. I gotta release them.
Narrator: *Something stirs deep within you, hungry and alert... it's taking something you'll never get back.*
Novice Grumm: Gnomes - it's your lucky day. Get your squat arses moving, before I take a brand to them.
