Player: I am freeing these gnomes. Just try and stop me.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: You're a monster hunter? Not what I imagined.
Gandrel: Hah. Perhaps that is why I have survived so long where more fearsome peers have not.
Gandrel: You would be wise to look past the seeming of things, if you intend to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Are you talking about Auntie Ethel?
Gandrel: A gentle name. But I speak of her nature.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: And are you fool enough?
Gandrel: Of course. I'm a hunter who lost his prey, and here I am seeking help from something worse.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Maybe I can help with your hunt.
: True
Gandrel: No. This duty is mine alone. But for such an offer, an answer at least is owed.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You can give up your hunt. Astarion's under my protection.
Gandrel: ...I see. Your loyalty is admirable but misplaced. His kind have charm beyond our mortal means to resist.
Gandrel: I can show you who he truly is - if you will just tell me where to find him.
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: I'm not going to help you find him. Back off.

Ptaris: Who are you? Another who needs to learn the difference between right and wrong?

Esther the expeditioner: S_GLO_Expeditioner_5f4048ba-72ef-43c2-9528-1c9a12f3f82f
Narrator: *A githyanki youth, and a familiar one at that. Can it be that this is the one who hatched from the egg you took from the crèche?*
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53]. Who are you?
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Was Lady Esther bad too?
Ptaris: She did not have the strength to be good. She was another like father - lacking in moral fibre.
NodeContext: Indifferent to the dead body at his feet.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I try to be, but sometimes my magic has other ideas.
Ptaris: There is no 'try'. You are either good or you are not.
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: What's the Ptarian code?
Ptaris: It is honour. Justice. The true form of goodness we all must live by, decreed by Bahamut himself.
Ptaris: You are not capable of following its teachings.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like Vlaakith's, but he knows nothing of the Protocols.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: I never should have saved you. But I'm happy to rectify my mistake.
Player: You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.
: True
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Dribbles stands atop the stage, a big smile on his face. Group of children crowded at the front.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Buddy the dog is my very best friend. Do you know why?
Quinton: Why?
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Because with him, anything is paw-sible. Wa-hey!
NodeContext: Big gestures at the 'wa-hey' (it's his 'signature' sound). Maybe jazz hands or a little dance?
Lae'zel: Can we not find a more pleasant amusement? Gouging out our own eyeballs, perhaps?
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Did you hear about the scarecrow who lost a fight?
Player: BOO! GET OFF THE STAGE!
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: You hear that, Buddy? We've got ourselves a Debbie Downer!
Quinton: Booo.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Thank you to the loudmouth for volunteering for my next trick! Now, where, oh, where are you...?
NodeContext: Puts his hands to his eyes and dramatically scans the crowd - suddenly locks eyes with the player.
Narrator: *A bloodthirsty rush of fury engulfs you. You want to butcher the crowd, women and children alike, and soak in their innards. It is glorious.*
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: You - my special assistant. Come on up.
Player: This clown's looking at you funny. What's his deal?
: True
Narrator: *You've been here before, and you'll be here again. The clown is sizing you up, getting your measure.*
Narrator: *It's a trap - one that this clown is eager to spring.*
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Come now, don't be a Cowardly Connie. Perhaps you need a little encouragement?
NodeContext: looks at crowd expectantly, raising his hands to 'give it up' for the player.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Now, up, up, double sharp! Or poor Buddy here might think you don't like him.
Player: Approach the stage.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: A round of applause for the stalwart heart!
NodeContext: Claps - loudly pleased and encouraging.
Karlach: Ah come on, soldier, you've been through worse - nearly.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Now, I always tell children that they're special. That each and every one of them is unique.
: True
Narrator: *You notice the clown reaching for something behind his back.*
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Tell me - what makes you special?
NodeContext: eager and earnest. Very much like he's talking to a child (he's not, he's talking to the player)
Player: I can magically transform into an animal at will.

Player: I sought purpose in the natural world - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Varsh Ko'kuu: This hatchery is a place of solemn duty and care. No one approaches an egg without my permission.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Of course, a stranger from a strange crèche may have different customs. What brings you here?
Player: I am here to help you save the egg.
Varsh Ko'kuu: This egg is in my care. It does not need saving.
Varsh Ko'kuu: It is a little slower to hatch, nothing more.
Lae'zel: Failure at the first hurdle of existence. Most caretakers would crush it and be done.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Most caretakers would not give the child its fair chance, but I shall. There could be greatness in that shell.
: True
Narrator: *You note that the hope in his voice is tinged with weariness. It's the voice of a man who's fought the inevitable for a long time.*
Player: Tell me the truth. Why do you really care about this one so much?
: True
Varsh Ko'kuu: Not all that arrive late are weak. I created this entire hatchery, despite being the last of my clutch to hatch.
Varsh Ko'kuu: They almost drowned me in the hatching pool. If it wasn't for the varsh of my clutch -
Varsh Ko'kuu: This one deserves the same chance.
Player: This seems like an awful lot of fuss for one egg.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Kith'rak Therezzyn is of the same opinion. She would see it destroyed and forgotten.
Varsh Ko'kuu: I'll give it a while longer, and if it doesn't hatch - it will have proven her right.
Player: Why risk its life at all? Give it to me - I'll take care of it.
: True
Varsh Ko'kuu: You? What do you know about githyanki child-rearing?
Varsh Ko'kuu: Still, the captain's due for an inspection any day now, and if she sees it here...
NodeContext: the captain will destroy his precious egg if she finds it
Varsh Ko'kuu: Tell me, what will you do with it if I entrust it to you?
Player: I'll see that it becomes the greatest ghaik-slayer you've ever seen.

Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.

Player: Who was your father?

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: Thank you so - no, it can't be. Wyll, by the living gods, what's happened to you?
Player: That's my business, and no one else's.
Counsellor Florrick: I won't press for answers you won't give.
Narrator: *She is a ghost from your past come to haunt you - Counsellor Florrick, your father's closest confidante, and a loyal servant of Baldur's Gate.*
Counsellor Florrick: It takes more than mere fire to break me, Pavel.
Counsellor Florrick: Now listen close, fist: duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed.
Counsellor Florrick: Aelis - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Counsellor Florrick: Gauntlet - report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Fist Recruit Ito: On your command, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: The rest of you - count the dead. Take word of their sacrifice to the city.
Counsellor Florrick: And you - I must ask again for your aid.
Counsellor Florrick: Please - rescue Ravengard from his drow captors. The Council will reward you for your effort.
Counsellor Florrick: May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: Goblins take their prisoners to Moonrise Towers. That's where we'll find the duke.
Counsellor Florrick: Moonrise Towers? Along the old road? That place is cursed. Few could survive there...
Counsellor Florrick: ... unless darker forces are at work.
Counsellor Florrick: This was no random attack. The Grand Duke was their target.
Player: On my oath: I will see Duke Ravengard rescued, and his captors vanquished.
Player: I'll search for Duke Ravengard.

Rugan: By the gods, you're a sweet sight.
Rugan: Are any of my crew still alive out there?
Player: No. It's a grim sight.
Rugan: This whole journey's been one grim sight after another. Gnolls, goblins... drow.
Rugan: Risen Road's more dangerous than ever. You're the first friendly face we've seen since Elturgard.
Player: Elturgard's a long way from here. Where are you heading?
Rugan: We're bound for Baldur's Gate - got some cargo to deliver. But we've a stop to make along the way.
Player: Where's that?
Rugan: Waukeen's Rest. It's just up the road. I'd be enjoying a mug of ale right now if those beasts hadn't jumped us.
Rugan: Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself.
Rugan: You should meet my associates. We've got our own drinking spot by the tavern - invitation only.
Rugan: Tell the fellow on the door 'little serpent, long shadow'. He'll take good care of you.
Olly: Rugan!
Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: Read his thoughts.
: True
Rugan: Shame we lost so many agents. But the chest is all that matters - Zarys'd have our hides if we lost it.
Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: What's in the chest? Your cargo?
Rugan: Aye. The whole reason we're in this mess. Trinkets for some rich tosser in Baldur's Gate.
Rugan: He gets his shiny baubles, we get a handful of Tarenths.
: True
Narrator: *Tarenths are the currency of the Zhentarim - a network of merchants and mercenaries with few scruples.*
Narrator: *Tarenths are the currency of a merchant network called the Zhentarim. Led by the mysterious Pereghost of Darkhold, their dealings are far from scrupulous.*
Player: Whatever your cargo is, I'll take it as payment.
: True
Rugan: Listen - I'm indebted to you. And that's why I'm giving you a chance to walk away before you get yourself killed.
Rugan: You made short work of the gnolls... reckon you'd make shorter work of me and the boy.

Player: Zhentarim agents guarding a single chest. Curious.
Rugan: If there are valuable goods on the move, The Black Company's always involved.
Rugan: We're the grease that keeps the wheels of commerce turning.
Rugan: And we don't take kindly to people who meddle in our business.
Rugan: This is the point when a clever operator like you accepts my gratitude and walks away.
Player: Enough talking. I'll have that cargo, or I'll have your head.
Player: No. This is the point where I stop asking, and start cutting.
: False
Rugan: My associates will do worse to me than you ever could.
Rugan: Let's go our separate ways, and be thankful we're all in one piece.
Player: You had your chance. Either way, that cargo's mine.

Wyll: You just have to buy enough time to run. Come on. I believe in you. You can do this.
Player: Hey there. Can I have a word?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll turns to you, smiling.
Wyll: Well met. The Blade of Frontiers at your -
Narrator: *The man's smile bends downward, and his thoughts become yours.*
Narrator: *You are the Blade of Frontiers, racing through the wastes of Avernus. Just ahead, a diabolical figure - red skin, single curled horn - blazes with flame, bloodied greataxe held high.*
Narrator: *It's Karlach - the woman you met in the wilds.*
Wyll: Hells' great fires - you were on the ship.
Player: Another escapee? Thank the gods - I need all the friends I can get.
Wyll: Better friends than the ones hitching a ride in our skulls, at least.
Wyll: I'm sure you know the stories. Doomed to shed our skin and become illithid. They say there's no coming back.
Wyll: But we haven't sprouted any tentacles - not yet, anyway. Could just be good luck. I'm not so...
Narrator: *Your minds collide once more. Wyll chases the fiend, ignited with rancour. She is an infernal wardevil, a threat to the living - evil incarnate.*
Wyll: Shit - you saw her: advocatus diaboli.
: False
Narrator: *Advocatus diaboli. A devil's advocate - a champion in the Blood War between diabolical forces and demons.*
Player: Also known as Karlach. She's in the wilds, some ways from here.
Wyll: You met her? Then you were subject to her lies.
Wyll: Karlach is an archdevil's soldier I swore on my good eye to kill.
Wyll: I tracked her through the Hells to the mind flayer ship. But the damned illithids infected me before I could end her.
Wyll: She's out there now, preying on the innocent. I don't kill her, she'll leave behind nothing but a trail of corpses.
Player: I'm looking to cure this infection. I suggest we partner up.
Wyll: Just so you know, my first duty is Karlach. I'm oathbound to go after her.
Wyll: But I won't deny this infection is bothersome.
Wyll: I accept your invitation.
Wyll: I'm up for the challenge. You've just got to make a little space.
Player: All right. Meet me at camp.
Wyll: A splendid plan. We'll talk more there.

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: I heard what happened - that people were taken to Moonrise.
Alfira: I keep replaying it... over and over in my head.
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I'm so sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: You're lucky to be alive.
Alfira: I don't feel lucky. I feel... I feel like I'm at the end of my rope.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: It helps to remember what is at stake - I fight for nature, for balance. I fight for life itself.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I'll do everything in my power to save them - you have my most solemn vow.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Dribbles stands atop the stage, a big smile on his face. Group of children crowded at the front.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Buddy the dog is my very best friend. Do you know why?
Quinton: Why?
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Because with him, anything is paw-sible. Wa-hey!
NodeContext: Big gestures at the 'wa-hey' (it's his 'signature' sound). Maybe jazz hands or a little dance?
Lae'zel: Can we not find a more pleasant amusement? Gouging out our own eyeballs, perhaps?
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Did you hear about the scarecrow who lost a fight?
Player: What a corny joke.

NodeContext: Big gestures at the 'wa-hey' (it's his 'signature' sound). Maybe jazz hands or a little dance?

NodeContext: Puts his hands to his eyes and dramatically scans the crowd - suddenly locks eyes with the player.

GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: A round of applause for the stalwart heart!

Shadowheart: I'm glad you volunteered - I didn't want to have to shove you forward in my place.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Now, I always tell children that they're special. That each and every one of them is unique.
Narrator: *You notice the clown reaching for something behind his back.*
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Tell me - what makes you special?
NodeContext: eager and earnest. Very much like he's talking to a child (he's not, he's talking to the player)
Player: I can magically transform into an animal at will.

Zevlor: Ngh. Mragreshem.
NodeContext: mrag-RESH-em. Means 'shithead' in infernal. Zevlor has just woken up after being punched in the face by Aradin. He's groggy and pissed off.
Zevlor: A cheap shot. I should've expected that.
NodeContext: Disgust in his voice. His idiot enemy clocked him.
Player: Are you all right?
Zevlor: I'll survive a sore jaw. Particularly if it's rid the grove of Aradin.
Zevlor: Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I have no quarrel with druids.
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
: True
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: Is there a place for tieflings anywhere?
Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded.
Zevlor: But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Found sanctuary here, did you?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me.
Zevlor: You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place.
Zevlor: Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer.
Player: I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Player: I'm glad you made it too, it's one hell of a curse.
Alfira: It wasn't the curse that did us in.
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.

Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Ikaron again?
Alfira: Which...? He was on the quiet side, but had a heart of gold. Back in the grove, he'd kept an eye on the kids. Gods, that feels like a lifetime ago.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: You're lucky to be alive.
Alfira: I don't feel lucky. I feel... I feel like I'm at the end of my rope.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - there is no greater thrill for me than the hunt.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I'll do everything in my power to save them - you have my most solemn vow.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: We share a profession, it seems. I'm Wyll - better known as the Blade of Frontiers.
Gandrel: Ah, the Blade of Frontiers! You wield that reputation as deftly as a blade itself.
Gandrel: Your name should serve you well when you meet with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: My business here is my own.
Gandrel: As you like. But you needn't be coy - whatever's worth knowing, rest assured she already knows it.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: Speak plainly. What is she?
Gandrel: A powerful friend. A terrible foe. That, I cannot decide for you.
Gandrel: For my part - I need her knowledge. The thing I hunt has gone to ground.
Gandrel: If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Your coyness is getting boring. Tell me.
: True
Gandrel: You take insult where none is intended, my friend. But fine - I won't add to it.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You're wasting your time. Astarion's been dealt with.
Gandrel: You know him? Not too well, I think, if you believe he is so easily slain. He could be stalking your camp at this very moment.
Gandrel: Perhaps you could tell me where to look, and I could ensure peace of mind for us both?
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: I'm not going to help you find him. Back off.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Be in awe, Truest Soul. The new dawn will rise.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.

Barcus Wroot: Well. You... did it!
Barcus Wroot: I shouldn't be surprised, considering our history. And yet...
Player: I did. But not out of the kindness of my heart.
Barcus Wroot: I have no coin, but the foreman will be happy to provide.
Barcus Wroot: Nothing good happens in the Underdark.
Barcus Wroot: I don't know if you heard, but some of the Ironhand Gnomes - my friend Wulbren among them - have been taken prisoner in Moonrise Towers.
Barcus Wroot: I know someone of your background would fit right in in that heart of horrors, but for others of us it's quite a frightening prospect.
Barcus Wroot: And so... to Moonrise Towers I go.

Kith'rak Voss: What easy prey you make, walking right within my blade's embrace.
Kith'rak Voss: These creatures are so simple to ensnare, Baretha. You mewl too much about your task.
Sarth Baretha: Forgiveness, Kith'rak.
Kith'rak Voss: And as for you, tell me - why shouldn't I run you through this instant?
Player: You'd sprain your wrist trying.
: True
Kith'rak Voss: Senseless creature - I don't want to dull my blade on your overly thick skull.
Kith'rak Voss: But your bravery amuses me. Finally I find a wolf in a world of lowing cattle...
Kith'rak Voss: You may live. For the moment.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: A student, yes. Do please enlighten me.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: You do me an honour, but I am not worthy. Show me the way of Shar - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: You're a monster hunter? Not what I imagined.
Gandrel: Hah. Perhaps that is why I have survived so long where more fearsome peers have not.
Gandrel: You would be wise to look past the seeming of things, if you intend to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Not at all. I was invited for tea.
Gandrel: Of course - as the spider invites the fly. You need something, I expect. And she sensed it.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: So I learned.
Gandrel: Ah - so you did. I thought you were just squinting from the stink.
Gandrel: But, one fool to another, I can't say I judge you. The thing I hunt has slipped away from me.
Gandrel: If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: I like danger. The truth - now.
: True
Gandrel: Perhaps I was... hasty with my words.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: I know Astarion - he's no vampire.
Gandrel: So you have met him. His kind have charm beyond our mortal means to resist.
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: I'm not going to help you find him. Back off.

: True
Rugan: Fine - no need for more violence. I'll tell my associates everything was lost in the ambush.

Rugan: And no hard feelings, y'hear? I'd have done the same if I were you. Business at the end of a blade is still business.
Rugan: Crafty swine like you could make a name for yourself in the Zhentarim. Make sure to drop by our hideout.
Rugan: Pass phrase at the door is 'little serpent, long shadow'. I'll tell my associates to expect you.
Player: I already met your friends - we didn't get along too well.
Rugan: And yet here you are. There's not many cause trouble in a Zhent hideout and walk away.
Rugan: I'd rather walk away too. So let's say our goodbyes, and speak no more of it.

Fezzerk: Look what we got here - another little birdie wantin' to fly!
NodeContext: Cruel bravado.The goblin sees the player approach and boldly announces it to his cronies - he thinks some fresh victims have just turned up.
Fezzerk: Yehehueh! Enjoyin' yerself? Sun ain't too bright in those beady little eyes?

'Yehehueh!' = Fezzerk's distinct laugh (a raspy, mean-spirited slur of a laugh)
Fezzerk: An' you - hope you got a stomach fer heights!
NodeContext: Confident, unpleasant. Turning his attention to the player to deliver a threat.
Player: I won't interfere. I just want to pass by.
Fezzerk: Heh, funny. That's what our birdie wanted.
Barcus Wroot: ...Release me this instant, you beasts!
NodeContext: Panicked, angry. Issuing an ultimatum even though he has no means of following through on it.
Fezzerk: 'Less you wanna join him up there, you'd best pay the toll.
NodeContext: Confident, threatening. Thinks he holds all the cards in a one-sided negotiation.
Fezzerk: Cough it up! ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Player: I've changed my mind - release the gnome and clear off. Or else.

Fezzerk: You want this little cave-lurkin' wotsit?

Fezzerk: Find your own! He's ours!

NodeContext: Narration
Fezzerk: We're leaving.
Goblin Devout: What about the gnome? Ain't we s'posed to bring him to -
Fezzerk: I said we're leaving!
Fezzerk: There's plenty of sport an' rich pickings out there fer us. Move it!

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?

Barcus Wroot: Well. You... did it!
Barcus Wroot: I shouldn't be surprised, considering our history. And yet...

Barcus Wroot: I have no coin, but the foreman will be happy to provide.
Barcus Wroot: Nothing good happens in the Underdark.
Barcus Wroot: I know someone of your background would fit right in in that heart of horrors, but for others of us it's quite a frightening prospect.
Barcus Wroot: And so... to Moonrise Towers I go.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Dribbles stands atop the stage, a big smile on his face. Group of children crowded at the front.

Quinton: Why?
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Because with him, anything is paw-sible. Wa-hey!

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Perhaps not. Patience is important, but cannot impede the other virtues.
Havkelaag: Then we are in accord - the time for action is now.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Gale: A beautiful night, don't you think? Nothing like a brush with destruction to make one appreciate the majesty of the celestial canvas.
Gale: It's a view I would once have shared with my companion. Though definitely unaccompanied by such revelry.
Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: Are you... are you talking about your cat?
Gale: By Ahghairon's lost nose - no!
Gale: Tara is not any cat. She's a tressym. And given your confusion, I'm guessing you've never met one. They're brilliant creatures - fine company for any self-respecting wizard.
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be most impressed by our efforts saving these tieflings. Proud, even. And I've given her little to be proud of recently.
Gale: After I was afflicted with my condition, I locked myself in my tower for an entire year. I was inconsolable, wallowing in my self-inflicted tragedy.
Gale: I'd given up on myself, but Tara never did. It was her encouragement, her research that led me to my treatment. Once we knew that magically-infused items were the key, she went out to find them for me. She saved my life.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: What is Tara like?
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. The same sharp tongue. And sharp teeth.
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: What if she doesn't like me?
Gale: She'll love you. So long as you don't rub her belly. She hates it when anyone does that.
Player: Not as much as I hate talking about cats. Is there nothing else on your mind?
Gale: Not an animal lover? Nobody's perfect, I suppose.
Gale: Nonetheless, your finer qualities are remarkably plentiful.
Gale: Suffice it to say, I think rather a lot of you. And there aren't many on this plane who I'd give such high praise.
Player: I'm flattered. Is your good opinion so hard to come by?
Gale: One doesn't become the most powerful archmage in Waterdeep and lover to the goddess of magic herself by having low standards.
Gale: I assure you, when I tell someone they're wonderful - I mean it. And you are wonderful.
Gale: I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: Actually, I was thinking we'd be wonderful together...
Gale: Wait. Are you saying...
Gale: I see. Then perhaps we see each other in the same light after all. A resplendent one, flush with warmth and anticipation, but one which I must shy away from, for now.

Gale: There you are. I was worried you might have second thoughts after my little confrontation with Mystra.
Gale: Most would think me foolish, deluded even, for daring to pursue dreams of wielding Karsus' Crown. I do not take your faith lightly.
Gale: Words alone are not enough. Permit me to show you. Please, close your eyes a moment.
Player: Close your eyes.
Gale: Astra navigabimus.
NodeContext: Latin spellcasting - ass-tra navi-gah-mus ('we sail the stars')
Gale: Few mortals ever glimpse what you're about to see. But don't be alarmed - I'm here with you. Now... open your eyes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up from black as the player opens their eyes to a dazzling spectacle. They and Gale are now sitting in a small boat that shimmers with iridescent light. Unpiloted, it silently meanders through a majestic, infinite starfield.
Gale: The Outer Planes. This is where gods dwell. Where they observe us from afar. Where they make play-things of us.
Gale: They would keep all of this from us - the power, the possibilities. They only want us to serve them, pray to them... and ultimately, die for them.
Gale: But what if we didn't need them? What if we wielded their power instead, and helped ourselves in all the ways they refuse to. I could make that happen. I could make this illusion a reality, with you by my side.
Player: You're still determined to do this, after all that was said?
Gale: How could I not crave this? But I don't want it for myself, alone - I want you at my side, willing and wholehearted.
Gale: The tadpoles, the orb - these threats to our existence - the gods could aid us if they wished, but instead they cower behind Ao. So let us act ourselves.
NodeContext: Ao = AY-oh (an overlord deity that most gods answer to)
Gale: With the power of the crown, any foe would be rendered impotent. Any obstacle would be dwarfed by our might.
Gale: I used to believe Mystra's forgiveness was worth dying for. But I was wrong. You showed me just how much I have to live for.
Gale: With you, I forget my goddess. I love you.
Gale: Tell me you feel the same way. Tell me you want what I want. Please.
Player: I feel the same. Whatever you need of me, consider it done.
Gale: Right now, I need nothing more than a kiss. Then we'll face what is to come, together. And claim the crown when the time comes.
Player: Let's not grow complacent - that path you speak of is sure to be a dangerous one.
Gale: No doubt it will be - abominably so. As is just about everything we do. But I know we're up to the task. Are you still with me?
Gale: You mean... you want the same as I do?
NodeContext: Hope rising again
Player: I can't, Gale. This is best forgotten. I love you as you are.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale's shoulders sag. The starfield around seems to dim. Distant points of light vanish into the infinite dark.
Gale: What more is there to be said?
Player: Plenty, in time. This doesn't have to be the end for us - just forget the crown.
Gale: But I could be so much more to you.
NodeContext: crestfallen
Player: You're already everything I need you to be.
Gale: I hope you're right. I truly do. Godly power, perhaps I can live without, but you? You're everything.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player and Gale lean in to kiss while seated facing each other.
Gale: You put the stars to shame. Let's sit here another while - I want to drink you in.

Gale: Tara is not any cat. She's a tressym. And given your confusion, I'm guessing you've never met one. They're brilliant creatures - fine company for any self-respecting wizard.
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be proud to see me keeping such fine company - the saviour of those poor tieflings, no less. And I've given her precious little to be proud of recently.
Gale: She has a good heart, and she would recognise the same in your actions here. I'm sure she'd approve of me lending myself to your efforts.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: She must be very smart, to have done all that.
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. You share a certain nobility of spirit.
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.

Gale: Suffice it to say, I think rather a lot of you. And there aren't many on this plane who I'd give such high praise.
Player: I'm flattered. Is your good opinion so hard to come by?
Gale: One doesn't become the most powerful archmage in Waterdeep and lover to the goddess of magic herself by having low standards.

Gale: I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.

Gale: Wait. Are you saying...
Gale: You know what, I think I've clearly had far too much wine. And you've had nowhere near enough. I think this is a conversation best held back on - for now.

Gale: Ah, you've a moment for me? I was hoping to speak to you - I confess, my thoughts have been somewhat scattered since my audience with Mystra.
Gale: The Karsite Weave could offer more than just power - it could bestow divinity. If I only trust myself to wield it.
Gale: The power to change the world - it may be within our reach. You must have an opinion, surely.
Player: I'm here to support you, no matter what you want.
Gale: Words alone are not enough. Permit me to show you. Please, close your eyes a moment.
Player: Close your eyes.
Gale: Astra navigabimus.
NodeContext: Latin spellcasting - ass-tra navi-gah-mus ('we sail the stars')
Gale: Few mortals ever glimpse what you're about to see. But don't be alarmed - I'm here with you. Now... open your eyes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up from black as the player opens their eyes to a dazzling spectacle. They and Gale are now sitting in a small boat that shimmers with iridescent light. Unpiloted, it silently meanders through a majestic, infinite starfield.
Gale: The Outer Planes. This is where gods dwell. Where they observe us from afar. Where they make play-things of us.
Gale: They would keep all of this from us - the power, the possibilities. They only want us to serve them, pray to them... and ultimately, die for them.
Gale: But what if we didn't need them? What if we wielded their power instead, and helped ourselves in all the ways they refuse to. I could make that happen. I could make this illusion a reality, with you by my side.
Player: You're still determined to do this, after all that was said?
Gale: How could I not crave this? But I don't want it for myself, alone - I want you at my side, willing and wholehearted.
Gale: The tadpoles, the orb - these threats to our existence - the gods could aid us if they wished, but instead they cower behind Ao. So let us act ourselves.
NodeContext: Ao = AY-oh (an overlord deity that most gods answer to)
Gale: With the power of the crown, any foe would be rendered impotent. Any obstacle would be dwarfed by our might.
Gale: I used to believe Mystra's forgiveness was worth dying for. But I was wrong. You showed me just how much I have to live for.
Gale: With you, I forget my goddess. I love you.
Gale: Tell me you feel the same way. Tell me you want what I want. Please.
Player: I feel the same. Whatever you need of me, consider it done.
Gale: Right now, I need nothing more than a kiss. Then we'll face what is to come, together. And claim the crown when the time comes.
Player: Wait. Perhaps I'm being too hasty... and perhaps you're overreaching.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale's shoulders sag. The starfield around seems to dim. Distant points of light vanish into the infinite dark.
Gale: What more is there to be said?
Player: Plenty, in time. This doesn't have to be the end for us - just forget the crown.
Gale: But I could be so much more to you.
NodeContext: crestfallen
Player: Say nothing. Answer him with a kiss instead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player and Gale lean in to kiss while seated facing each other.
Gale: You put the stars to shame. Let's sit here another while - I want to drink you in.

Gale: Even in such fraught times as these, there is peace to be found in the stillness as evening draws in.
Gale: I used to while away many hours just like these with my companion, though in far comfier surrounds.
Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: Sounds, er, fun.
Gale: Not everyone is comfortable being alone with their thoughts. Though I never felt alone with a book in my hand. Or with her for company.
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be proud to see me keeping such fine company - the saviour of those poor tieflings, no less. And I've given her precious little to be proud of recently.
Gale: She has a good heart, and she would recognise the same in your actions here. I'm sure she'd approve of me lending myself to your efforts.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: What is Tara like?
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. There's a steeliness to you, an unwavering tenacity even in the face of, to be frank, quite dire odds.
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: So I remind you of your pet? How romantic...
Gale: I assure you, were you to meet Tara you would see the comparison for the flattery it is. But perhaps that's not a point worth labouring further.
Gale: Suffice it to say, I think rather a lot of you. And there aren't many on this plane who I'd give such high praise.
Player: Being mentioned in the same breath as your pet isn't the compliment you think it is...
Gale: Then let me say it more plainly -
Gale: I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: Actually, I was thinking we'd be wonderful together...
Gale: Wait. Are you saying...
Gale: I see. Then perhaps we see each other in the same light after all. A resplendent one, flush with warmth and anticipation, but one which I must shy away from, for now.

Gale: I must admit, the Crown of Karsus has occupied my every thought since we learned of it.
Gale: If we can seize it, and use it... the possibilities are endless. Yet you haven't uttered a peep one way or the other about it.
Gale: The power to change the world - it may be within our reach. You must have an opinion, surely.
Player: I don't know what to say. How can I respond to something so... immense? It's beyond comprehension.
Gale: Then the fault lies with me, and my inadequate words. Please, allow me to show you instead. Just close your eyes a moment.
Gale: Words alone are not enough. Permit me to show you. Please, close your eyes a moment.
Player: Close your eyes.
Gale: Astra navigabimus.
NodeContext: Latin spellcasting - ass-tra navi-gah-mus ('we sail the stars')
Gale: Few mortals ever glimpse what you're about to see. But don't be alarmed - I'm here with you. Now... open your eyes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up from black as the player opens their eyes to a dazzling spectacle. They and Gale are now sitting in a small boat that shimmers with iridescent light. Unpiloted, it silently meanders through a majestic, infinite starfield.
Gale: The Outer Planes. This is where gods dwell. Where they observe us from afar. Where they make play-things of us.
Gale: They would keep all of this from us - the power, the possibilities. They only want us to serve them, pray to them... and ultimately, die for them.
Gale: But what if we didn't need them? What if we wielded their power instead, and helped ourselves in all the ways they refuse to. I could make that happen. I could make this illusion a reality, with you by my side.
Player: Are you saying you want to ascend? Claim godhood?
Gale: No, not like that. I don't want to join them, I want to better them. A god's powers, paired with a mortal conscience, a mortal heart.
Gale: The tadpoles, the orb - these threats to our existence - the gods could aid us if they wished, but instead they cower behind Ao. So let us act ourselves.
NodeContext: Ao = AY-oh (an overlord deity that most gods answer to)
Gale: With the power of the crown, any foe would be rendered impotent. Any obstacle would be dwarfed by our might.
Gale: I used to believe Mystra's forgiveness was worth dying for. But I was wrong. You showed me just how much I have to live for.
Gale: With you, I forget my goddess. I love you.
Gale: Tell me you feel the same way. Tell me you want what I want. Please.
Player: I love you. But for the man that you are. Not the god you'd pretend to be.
Gale: But think what I offer. The vastness of eternity to explore, the Weave at our fingertips... You would really prefer me as I am?
Player: You're already everything I need you to be.
Gale: I hope you're right. I truly do. Godly power, perhaps I can live without, but you? You're everything.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player and Gale lean in to kiss while seated facing each other.
Gale: You put the stars to shame. Let's sit here another while - I want to drink you in.

Gale: Even in such fraught times as these, there is peace to be found in the stillness as evening draws in.

Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: Are you... are you talking about your cat?
Gale: By Ahghairon's lost nose - no!
Gale: Tara is not any cat. She's a tressym. And given your confusion, I'm guessing you've never met one. They're brilliant creatures - fine company for any self-respecting wizard.
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be most impressed by our efforts saving these tieflings. Proud, even. And I've given her little to be proud of recently.
Gale: After I was afflicted with my condition, I locked myself in my tower for an entire year. I was inconsolable, wallowing in my self-inflicted tragedy.
Gale: I'd given up on myself, but Tara never did. It was her encouragement, her research that led me to my treatment. Once we knew that magically-infused items were the key, she went out to find them for me. She saved my life.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: She must be very smart, to have done all that.
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. You share a certain nobility of spirit.

Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.

Gale: Wait. Are you saying...

Gale: A beautiful night, don't you think? Nothing like a brush with destruction to make one appreciate the majesty of the celestial canvas.
Gale: It's a view I would once have shared with my companion. Though definitely unaccompanied by such revelry.
Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: I hope you aren't talking about Mystra again...

Gale: She'd be most impressed by our efforts saving these tieflings. Proud, even. And I've given her little to be proud of recently.
Gale: After I was afflicted with my condition, I locked myself in my tower for an entire year. I was inconsolable, wallowing in my self-inflicted tragedy.
Gale: I'd given up on myself, but Tara never did. It was her encouragement, her research that led me to my treatment. Once we knew that magically-infused items were the key, she went out to find them for me. She saved my life.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: What is Tara like?
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. An expression you both share - when she gives in to her more feline qualities, a mouse trapped beneath her paw...
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: What if she doesn't like me?
Gale: She'll love you. So long as you don't rub her belly. She hates it when anyone does that.
Player: She sounds great. But I was hoping I meant more to you than an animal companion...
Gale: I assure you, were you to meet Tara you would see the comparison for the flattery it is. But perhaps that's not a point worth labouring further.
Gale: Suffice it to say, I think rather a lot of you. And there aren't many on this plane who I'd give such high praise.
Player: I'm flattered. Is your good opinion so hard to come by?
Gale: One doesn't become the most powerful archmage in Waterdeep and lover to the goddess of magic herself by having low standards.
Gale: I assure you, when I tell someone they're wonderful - I mean it. And you are wonderful.
Gale: I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: Actually, I was thinking we'd be wonderful together...
Gale: Wait. Are you saying...
Gale: I see. Then perhaps we see each other in the same light after all. A resplendent one, flush with warmth and anticipation, but one which I must shy away from, for now.

Gale: Even in such fraught times as these, there is peace to be found in the stillness as evening draws in.
Gale: I used to while away many hours just like these with my companion, though in far comfier surrounds.
Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: Are you... are you talking about your cat?
Gale: By Ahghairon's lost nose - no!
Gale: Tara is not any cat. She's a tressym. And given your confusion, I'm guessing you've never met one. They're brilliant creatures - fine company for any self-respecting wizard.
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be proud to see me keeping such fine company - the saviour of those poor tieflings, no less. And I've given her precious little to be proud of recently.
Gale: She has a good heart, and she would recognise the same in your actions here. I'm sure she'd approve of me lending myself to your efforts.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: What is Tara like?

Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. You share a certain nobility of spirit.
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: You don't have any friends?
Gale: Sadly not. If I'm being entirely honest, my social circle is rather small. More of a dot. Or a pinhead.
Gale: I've got aquaintances, certainly. Plenty of colleagues. But friends? Those are precious indeed.
Gale: I hope, though we've only known each other for a short time, I might be able to count you among that number?
Player: Of course. I hoped we might be more than friends...
Gale: Wait. Are you saying...
Gale: I see. Then perhaps we see each other in the same light after all. A resplendent one, flush with warmth and anticipation, but one which I must shy away from, for now.

Gale: A beautiful night, don't you think? Nothing like a brush with destruction to make one appreciate the majesty of the celestial canvas.
Gale: It's a view I would once have shared with my companion. Though definitely unaccompanied by such revelry.
Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: Who are you referring to? A former lover, perhaps?
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be most impressed by our efforts saving these tieflings. Proud, even. And I've given her little to be proud of recently.
Gale: After I was afflicted with my condition, I locked myself in my tower for an entire year. I was inconsolable, wallowing in my self-inflicted tragedy.
Gale: I'd given up on myself, but Tara never did. It was her encouragement, her research that led me to my treatment. Once we knew that magically-infused items were the key, she went out to find them for me. She saved my life.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: She must be very smart, to have done all that.
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. The same sharp tongue. And sharp teeth.
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: So I remind you of your pet? How romantic...
Gale: I assure you, were you to meet Tara you would see the comparison for the flattery it is. But perhaps that's not a point worth labouring further.
Gale: Suffice it to say, I think rather a lot of you. And there aren't many on this plane who I'd give such high praise.
Player: I'm flattered. Is your good opinion so hard to come by?
Gale: One doesn't become the most powerful archmage in Waterdeep and lover to the goddess of magic herself by having low standards.
Gale: I assure you, when I tell someone they're wonderful - I mean it. And you are wonderful.
Gale: I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: Don't stop now. What else do you like about me?
Gale: Were I to recite that list, I fear we'd still be here at dusk tomorrow. Many things, I assure you, but a conversation better saved for another time.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: I'm afraid all of this is just a fantasy.
Gale: So it is. But a very fine one.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: You speak as if this affects you alone. How many will die if you unleash what's inside you?
Gale: Fewer than if the Absolute goes unchecked. I don't want to kill, and I don't want to die... but inaction will lead to bloodshed all the same.
Gale: I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: Why are you so sure it's inevitable? We haven't even found this 'Heart of the Absolute' yet.
Gale: I can feel it - ever since we set foot in this strange, corrupted land. The closer we get, the heavier my own heart becomes.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: One moment with you could sate me for a lifetime, and prise the fear from my heart. I'm so very glad you came, to share this with me.
Gale: I know this is all unreal, but I created it for you. You must know that you're... That you're very special to me.
Gale: If things were different, if we were home, I'd have taken the time to do things properly. To say it all better. But time is short.
Gale: I'm in love with you.
Player: Lean in for a kiss.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player and Gale kiss seated on the ground. It's relatively chaste.

Gale: I want it to be perfect - to bond with you in the way that gods do... intertwining our spirits in visions of the Weave.
Player: I don't need illusions. I want the Gale standing right in front of me.
Gale: Are you sure...? I could conjure up any sight that you could dream of, and a few you could not. I could use the Weave to make us feel sensations beyond reckoning. I could do more than woo you. I could wow you.
Player: You don't need to impress me, Gale. I'm no deity.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: You seem especially philosophical this evening. Are you all right?
Gale: I will be, soon. I am perhaps just one hard day away from being without any troubles at all.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: Are you not afraid?
Gale: Afraid? No, I am terrified. But fear or courage or reason cannot change the charge I've been given.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You're right. At least this way, you might take the Absolute down with you.
Gale: I can only hope that there are few innocents within the Absolute's reach, when the time comes... and that you will seek safety, far away from me.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: One moment with you could sate me for a lifetime, and prise the fear from my heart. I'm so very glad you came, to share this with me.
Gale: I know this is all unreal, but I created it for you. You must know that you're... That you're very special to me.
Gale: If things were different, if we were home, I'd have taken the time to do things properly. To say it all better. But time is short.
Gale: I'm in love with you.
Player: I'm in love with you too.
Gale: That's a relief. It would be a shame to spend my final hours making an ass of myself.
NodeContext: relieved chuckle
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player and Gale kiss seated on the ground. It's relatively chaste.
Player: You're a good kisser.
Gale: And you're a bad liar. I lived the life of a hermit for some time before I met you - safer for all, but not conducive to pleasures of the flesh.
Gale: I want it to be perfect - to bond with you in the way that gods do... intertwining our spirits in visions of the Weave.
Player: I don't need illusions. I want the Gale standing right in front of me.
Gale: Are you sure...? I could conjure up any sight that you could dream of, and a few you could not. I could use the Weave to make us feel sensations beyond reckoning. I could do more than woo you. I could wow you.
Player: You don't need to impress me, Gale. I'm no deity.
